critique: This document pertains to amendments to the Selective Service Regulations during the Korean War era. It focuses on deferments for students pursuing graduate degrees, specifically setting criteria based on academic performance and test scores. The document itself doesn't express a clear ideological stance, but its context within the Cold War and the need for skilled personnel might suggest a leaning towards prioritizing national interests. Immigration is not directly addressed. Executive power is somewhat expanded as it is an amendment. Federalism is strengthened as it is a federal mandate. National security is prioritized over individual liberty due to the draft. Economic regulation is not directly addressed. Social inclusion is limited as it only applies to male students.
